article.Heading: Budget 2017: Jaitley may scrap complicated accounting system ICDS
article.Summary: Easwar-panel on I-T simplification is also believed to have favoured replacing the ICDS with a simpler system. Industry bodies say this has increased compliance costs
article.Body:
Gaurav Choudhury & Shreya Nandi
Moneycontrol

Finance Minister Arun Jaitley may scrap the Income Computation and Disclosure Standards (ICDS), which companies have complained as complicated and riddled with drawbacks.

The RV Easwar-headed panel on income tax (I-T) simplification is also believed to have favoured replacing the ICDS with a simpler system. ICDS, which has been adopted since 2016-17, has resulted in multiple accounting systems—one for tax purposes and the other for books of accounts as mandated by the Companies Act.

Industry bodies and tax experts have pointed out that this has increased compliance costs and resulted in multiple interpretation of tax rules and business laws.

Large listed companies have adopted the “Indian Accounting Standards (IndAS)”—an globally accepted accounting standard introduced by the ministry of corporate affairs in India. The scope of IndAS will be widened from April 1, 2017.

Experts point out that the accounting system for tax and corporate filing purposes should be identical, arguing that there was no specific purpose that ICDS can achieve.

"It will be a good move if the government decides not to implement ICDS as it leads to additional compliance requirements," Prashant Khatore, Partner at E&Y said.

"People will have to maintain two different set of accounting records in order to arrive at a taxable income because their book results may be as per their accouting standards and they will have to adjust accounting difference and then arrive at a taxable income," Khatore said.

Arvind Srivatsan, Partner at Pricewaterhouse Coopers also echoed similar views.

According to Srivastsan, it has to be seen that whether ICDS is consistent with the government's overall theme of ease of doing business.

"...if the governmment were to implement this, what would be the impact of ICDS on tax collection? It does not have any impact on the organised sector," he said.
